Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High-Resolution Underway Air-Sea Observations in Drake Passage for Climate Science
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Drake Passage is the body of water between South America and the Western Antarctic Peninsula, thus connecting the Southern Atlantic and Southern Pacific Oceans through the unimpeded flow of the immense Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC).

Using the relatively frequent ferry crossings of the Drake Passage by the RV/AS LMGould, the USAP supply ship, this proposal will continue the of collection of upper ocean XBT temperature and XTCD salinity data in this natural chokepoint for the ACC. This will yield additional hydrographic observations on seasonal to interannual timescales, and on spatial scales ranging from the current core to mesoscale eddies. These high-resolution, multi-repeat transects (up to 6 ~7 crossings per year) are quality controlled, archived and made available to the broader community in order to facilitate study of the modes of variability of the dominant oceanic current on the planet (the ACC). The Drake Passage XBT/XCTD transect time series now extends back to 1996, and continues to add to a number of quantitative estimates of the long term trends in Southern Ocean fronts, surface water mass properties, their response to atmospheric forcing on climate relevant time scales. This proposal also seeks renewal of a near decadal time series effort measuring the underway surface partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) in regular transects across the Drake Passage.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Southern Ocean is critical to the carbon and energy budgets of the Earth. Deep waters that lie up to 2 kilometers below the sea surface in the tropics upwell to the surface in the Southern Ocean, where they come in contact with the atmosphere.  The uptake of atmospheric heat and anthropogenic carbon by these upwelled waters has the potential to slow the rate of climate change, but it is challenging to measure because the strong winds and waves of the Southern Ocean pose a harsh environment for making observations. A major focus of the project is to observe and characterize the Drake Passage region in order to establish a baseline and improve predictions of the Southern Ocean. This report gives outcomes from an award that provided 3 years of support for a long-term observational program that continues under renewed funding to the present.

To address our goals, we continued underway sampling of upper ocean temperature, salinity and ocean currents, atmospheric and oceanic CO2, atmospheric O2 and meteorological parameters from the repeated transits of the principal USAP supply vessel, the ARSV Laurence M. Gould (LMG) that crosses Drake Passage on average 22 times annually. These time series began more than a decade ago, and together they provide concurrent information of the physical and biogeochemical air-sea variability at high temporal and spatial resolution on a near year-round basis, an unmatched achievement in the Southern Ocean.

 The main questions we addressed over the 3-year award period are: 1) What physical processes are responsible for the distribution of kinetic energy in the main current of the Southern Ocean, the Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC)? 2) What variability has occurred in metrics such as ACC volume transport, water mass properties, and water mass boundaries (fronts)? 3) What physical and biogeochemical processes determine the balance of net community production in Drake Passage?

Ocean current data and a high-resolution numerical simulation were used to discriminate between different theories of ocean turbulence and to identify processes responsible for the distribution of kinetic energy in the upper ocean at submeso- to meso- scales (10 km to 300 km). Currents like the ACC that are associated with density fronts are expected to obey quasi-geostrophic dynamics, and we expected that the kinetic energy would match quasi-geostrophic predictions (where kinetic energy is released from instabilities of the fronts) at all length scales. Instead, more than half of the near-surface kinetic energy on scales from 10 km to 40 km in Drake Passage was found to be due to internal gravity waves. Although this study focused on Drake Passage, it raised the question of the ubiquity of internal waves, prompting new studies in other geographic regions (supported by other funding).

ACC transport in the upper 1000 m has remained relatively constant. The Polar Front, the central front of the ACC, has shifted poleward, as have the winds that drive it, but the amount of shifting of the front depends strongly on the time interval examined. The mean shift of  30 km per decade is modest. Temperature and salinity in Drake Passage have strong seasonal cycles in the near surface that are characterized by a distinct warming/freshening in the austral summer. A comparatively weak summer/winter cycle is found in wind magnitude and direction. Correlations with two major climate modes, the Southern Annular Mode and the El Nino/Southern Oscillation, were less than 0.5, and occurred at varying temporal lags. The southernmost latitudes demonstrated a long-term freshening and a warming, while the northernmost latitudes were characterized by an increase in salinity and a cooling.

We used the nutrient, carbon and temperature time series to examine the balance of net community production in the surface layer of the Southern Ocean. The calculation provided a validation of satellite-based productivity algorithms, which can be used to extend the analysis to other Southern Ocean regions.

Our observations and analyses have improved the estimate of the mean and time-varying ACC, the major current system of the Southern Ocean. They have been used to validate satellite retrievals, climatologies and numerical models. The data we collect is assimilated in a numerical model, the Southern Ocean State Estimate. We provide processed data sets that are publicly available and used by scientists within multiple disciplines (physics, biology, chemistry). We provide high-quality in situ data for other researchers interested in variability in upper ocean temperature, currents, acoustic backscatter, carbon, and atmospheric O2 and CO2, and for testing ocean and coupled climate models.

The XBT software and probe launcher developed for the project are widely used by the global Volunteer Observing Ship program. The ADCP software developed for the project is used by the US oceanographic fleet.

Publications resulting from this 3-year award include 4 peer-reviewed journal articles and 12 conference presentations.

The award contributed to education through support and training of 5 graduate students.
